--- title: "Annotation Tutorial 2: Integrating Zotero with Obsidian" subtitle: "Tutorial for an efficient academic workflow" description: "This post is the second part of a tutorial about academic workflow on annotation. How to export Zotero annotations (= highlighted text and comments) from PDFs, ePUB eBooks, and website snapshots into Obsidian and how to go back from your Obsidian notes to the exact position of the annotation to (re)cover the context?" author: "Peter Baumgartner" date: "2024-08-12" image: "zotero-integration-obsidian-logo-min.png" image-alt: "The Zotero application icon is on the left and the Obsidian icon on the right of the image. Both icons are with two arrows, one pointing from Zotero to Obsidian and the other from Obsidian to Zotero." categories: [academic, obsidian, workflow, zotero, how-to] date-modified: "2024-08-20" draft: false --- ## Zotero Integration with Obsidian ### Academic Workflow In the [first part of this annotation tutorial](../2024-08-20-annotations-with-zotero-version-7) I have described the different annotation types in Zotero version 7 and how to use them. Here in this second part I will explain a simple method to import Zotero annotations into Obsidian. These Obsidian notes will include a link to the source of the annotation (quote) in Zotero. These backlinks are an eminent important feature because one cannot always remember the original context of the citation. Especially if the creation of the annotation happened long ago or if the original purpose of the quote for a specific publication / research issue has changed you need to check and reassess the context of the quote. Only with looking up the annotation in the source document you can prevent redundant and superfluous information to remember the context of the quote. After reading and annotating it is important to elaborate on these highlighted content. The general strategy is to add, reformulate and include the citations in your paper in progress. But whatever these changes of the initially annotations it is important for an efficient workflow that you always have a reference to the original position of the citation. There are two strategies for the integration of your "research assistant" (Zotero) with your note-taking app (Obsidian): 1. Creating a note inside Zotero and importing it into Obsidian (this post). 2. Extracting all annotation directly from the document programmatically (the third part of the annotation tutorial). In both cases you need to install two plugins: [Better BibTeX](https://retorque.re/zotero-better-bibtex/) in Zotero and [Zotero Integration](https://github.com/mgmeyers/obsidian-zotero-integration) in Obsidian. ## Notes in Zotero ### Child and Standalone Notes Zotero knows two types of notes. (The type names are my inventions to facilitate the explanation): - **Child Note or Items Note** belongs to the item where it was created. It lives inside the Zotero item. - **Standalone Notes** lives in the appropriate Zotero item collection but does not belong to any specific Zotero item. This note type is helpful for writing notes for multiple items. Only the child note is an annotation because it fulfills the requirement of the annotation: It is anchored to specific text -- even if it consists itself of (a collection of) annotations. Both types of notes can be created either as individual notes or as a note that collects all highlights: - **Individual note**: This is a new, empty note item. You can write your text into the note directly, or you can also drag and drop annotations from the left column. - **Highlights note**: This note collects and copies all content created with the annotation types, as mentioned earlier. You are always free to add or change the note content. The distinctions between child and standalone notes are not carved in stone as you can always drag a standalone note into an appropriate Zotero item and so it convert into a child note. You can also drag the child note as an item itself in the Zotero middle pane and so it convert into a standalone note. ::: {.callout-important style="color: red;"} You can create as many notes you want. But only child notes will be imported into Obsidian with the Zotero Integration plugin. ::: ### How to create a child note #### Add Note from Annotations {#sec-add-note-from-annotation} 1. Select the Zotero item or the document (PDF, ePUB-eBook, website snapshot) inside the Zotero item . 2. Open context menu (right mouse click on my installation) 3. Select "Add Note from Annotations" #### Add (empty) Note 1. Select the Zotero item (not the document). 2. Open context menu (right mouse click on my installation) 3. Select "Add Note" ![How to add an empty child note: (1) Select the Zotero item (2) Open context menu and (3) Select 'Add Note'](zotero-integration-add-empty-child-note-min.png){#fig-empty-child-note fig-alt="alt-text" fig-align="center" width="70%" group="zotero-integration"} To repeat: An "child note" is a note that is sorted under a Zotero item, independently of where it was created initially. We generate child notes as the easiest way to export notes into Obsidian. This has the disadvantage that changes in the Zotero annotations need another export to Obsidian. We will, therefore, cover in the third part of the tutorial as an alternative a more complex way where the Obsidian plugin extracts the annotations programmatically from the Zotero document. ## Installing Plugins ### Better BibTeX and Zotero Integration For the import of annotations into Obsidian, we need two plugins. At the side of Zotero [Better BibTeX](https://retorque.re/zotero-better-bibtex/) and in Obsidian the [Zotero Integration](https://github.com/mgmeyers/obsidian-zotero-integration). - **Better BibTex** makes it easier to manage bibliographic data, especially for people authoring documents using text-based tool chains (e.g., based on [LaTeX](https://www.latex-project.org/) / [Markdown](https://www.markdownguide.org/)). This plugin has a rich functionality, but we are using it for the Obsidian-Zotero integration just for one feature: To create a file with citations and consistent [pandoc](https://pandoc.org/) cite keys. - **Zotero Integration** does the main work: It inserts and imports citations, bibliographies, notes, and PDF annotations from Zotero into Obsidian. For this functionality, it needs the installation of the Better BibTeX plugin as an enhancement for Zotero. ### Install "Better BibTeX" > To install a plugin in Zotero, download its `.xpi` file to your > computer. Then, in Zotero, click "Tools → Add-ons" and drag the `.xpi` > onto the Add-ons window. ([Plugins for > Zotero](https://www.zotero.org/support/plugins)) To find the latest version of the Better BibTeX `.xpi` file [click at this link here](https://github.com/retorquere/zotero-better-bibtex/releases/latest). For a more detailed installation procedure [see here](https://retorque.re/zotero-better-bibtex/installation/). ### Install "Zotero Integration" > In Obsidian, open Settings, on the left under Options open Community > Plugins, on Community Plugins select Browse and search for 'Zotero > Integration' ([Help, How do I install the > Plugin?](https://github.com/mgmeyers/obsidian-zotero-integration#help-how-do-i-install-the-plugin)). For more details, especially troubleshooting the installation, see the [README file of Better BibTeX](https://github.com/mgmeyers/obsidian-zotero-integration?tab=readme-ov-file). ## Zotero Integration Settings The last task is to adapt the settings of the Obsidian Zotero Integration plugin. 1. Open Preferences with the menu "Obsidian → Preferences…" or `CMD+,` (macOS) / `CTRL+,` (Windows). 2. Scroll the left column down to "Zotero Integration" and select this plugin. You will get a window with a similar content as in @fig-zotero-integration-settings. The look may differ depending on the Obsidian theme you are using. (I am using [Cybertron](https://github.com/nickmilo/Cybertron)) ![Top part of the "Zotero Integration" plugin settings. For the import method explained here you need only to complete the "General Settings".](zotero-integration-plugin-settings-min.png){#fig-zotero-integration-settings fig-alt="The screenshot shows the general settings for importing annotated PDF files. The different fields are explained in the text." fig-align="center" width="70%" group="zotero-integration"} The configuration setting page for the "Zotero Integration" plugin is complex. It consists of four parts: - General Settings - Citation Formats and - Import Formats - Import Image Settings Although there are many preferences for the simple import method used in this post we only will need to complete the general settings. ### General Settings The first two settings provide the path to the main utility program for extracting data from PDFs. [pdfannots2json.js](https://github.com/mgmeyers/pdfannots2json/releases) should work immediately after the installation of the "Zotero Integration" plugin. Otherwise you have to download the tool and provide a path to it. In the third field you specify the program you are going to use. The plugin supports beside Zotero also [the Jurism project](https://juris-m.github.io/), specialized for legal research but also based on the Zotero reference manager. For advanced usage you have also the option to specify a custom port number. The default port where Zotero is listening is `23119`. You need to change it only for a special Zotero configuration, e.g., when you are using Zotero on a terminal server. In the next field you specify the path in Obsidian where the Zotero annotations should be stored. I have used with "zotero" a subdirectory of "annotation" because I have with [Calibre](https://calibre-ebook.com/) another app where I am importing annotations into Obsidian. The next two fields determine if Obsidian should open the imported file and in the case you have imported several at once, which of the imported files. The last option of the general settings is the possibility to enable concatenation of annotation. Although I have it turned on I haven't used this functionality so far. Instead to concatenate files I have used to separate new data (updates) via a template functions, which I will explain in the third part of the tutorial. ## Import Annotation into Obsidian without Template For this procedure you need to create the annotation file in Zotero manuallyas I have already explained in @sec-add-note-from-annotation. ![Obsidian [Command Palette](https://help.obsidian.md/Plugins/Command+palette) displaying all available commands of the Zotero Integration plugin. For some of the commands I have assigned hotkeys.](zotero-integration-command-palette-min.png){#fig-obsidian-command-palette fig-alt="alt-text" fig-align="center" width="70%" group="zotero-integration"} 1. Now change to Obsidian and choose either "Import notes" or "Insert notes into current document" from the command palette. If you attach shortcuts to these procedures you don't need to call the command via the Obsidian palette. 2. You have to wait until a window with the Zotero database appears, where you can select the appropriate Zotero item. All note files inside the Zotero item will be exported. The first command ("Import notes") creates a new file; the second command inserts the annotations into the cursor position of the current Obsidian document. 3. The result are annotations with two links: "Go to annotation" and the citation using the appropriate Zotero citation style. "Go to annotation" opens the PDF and jumps to the location of the annotation in the original document. The citation link selects the appropriate bibliography item in the Zotero middle pane. ![An example of an annotation file. Every entry starts with a link to the exact position of the quote and ends with a link to the bibliography entry in the Zotero middle pane. Between these two links is the annotated text passage surrounded by quotation marks.](zotero-integration-example-without-template-min.png){#fig-annotation-example fig-alt="alt-text" fig-align="center" width="70%" group="zotero-integration"} ## Summary In this post I have explained how to integrate your "research assistant" tool Zotero with the note-taking app Obsidian. ::: my-procedure ::: my-procedure-header Import Annotations from Zotero into Obsidian (without template) ::: ::: my-procedure-container 1. Highlight or use other annotation methods in Zotero as explained in the [first part of this tutorial](../2024-08-20-annotations-with-zotero-version-7). 2. Create a note with the annotations in Zotero. 3. Install the necessary plugins: [Better BibTeX](https://retorque.re/zotero-better-bibtex/) in Zotero and [Zotero Integration](https://github.com/mgmeyers/obsidian-zotero-integration) in Obsidian. 4. Complete the 'General Settings" part of the "Zotero Integration" plugin in Obsidian. 5. Choose either "Import notes" or "Include notes into current document" into Obsidian. 6. Wait for the Zotero dialog window and choose the Zotero item with the annotations. 7. Inspect the imported file content and test the links. ::: ::: You can now elaborate on your notes using all the advanced features Obsidian offers! In the third part of the annotation tutorial I will explain how to use templates for a programmatically extraction of annotations from Zotero documents. This has several advantages but it is more complex to apply. But maybe you are already satisfied with the result we obtained with this second part of the tutorial? The you can skip the last part or read it later when the need of a better management of your different types of annotation arise. ###### Glossary ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
